chapter.title: Supporting adults with LD in the self-disclosure process
chapter.content:
Supporting adults with LD in the self-disclosure process

We’ve talked about this multifaceted approach and how complicated it is, so how do individuals learn methods for self-disclosure?

In general, individuals with LD need help to develop self-understanding and to find compensatory strategies and accommodations that work. This fact highlights the importance of educators helping students develop self-determination. Let’s take a look at what you can do to support adult students with LD in the self-disclosure process.

chapter.title: Activity: Reflect on your program’s intake process
chapter.content:
Activity: Reflect on your program’s intake process

To wrap up our discussion on self-disclosure, let’s take some time to examine supports for self-disclosure in adult education settings – specifically in your own program or organization.

Take a moment to reflect on the intake process in your organization. Consider the following questions:

  1. What forms and procedures does your program use during the intake process that might allow an individual to disclose a learning disability? 
  2. How does your organization currently support individuals with suspected LD to develop the important skill of self-disclosure?

Click the forward arrow when you have completed your reflections.

chapter.title: Supporting the development of self-disclosure skills
chapter.content:
Supporting the development of self-disclosure skills

Here are a few examples of support programs you may have in place, or can implement,  to support the development of self-disclosure skills.

  • For teachers, support for self-disclosure can be as simple as inviting individuals who have LD (or other disabilities) to self-disclose. This can be a simple oral invitation when a class begins. In open enrollment courses, this can be done when groups of new individuals enter the class or program.
  • With informed consent, mentors and or tutors can support individuals with LD by providing instruction and practice in self-disclosure skills.

chapter.title: Support for individuals without documentation of their LD
chapter.content:
Support for individuals without documentation of their LD

As mentioned before, an individual with suspected learning disabilities may not have and/or may not be able to obtain documentation. Again, with informed consent, you can still try to help these individuals build self-disclosure skills as well as improve their success in your program.

Teachers, counselors, mentors, and/or tutors can:

  • invite students to tell what in the past has indicated that he or she has a learning disability;
  • encourage them to explore and discuss their strengths and weaknesses as learners and employees; or
  • ask them to share what strategies have (and have not) assisted them in completing learning and/or work related tasks.

chapter.title: Confidentiality at intake
chapter.content:
Confidentiality at intake

When considering your organization’s intake and support processes in regard to self-disclosure, it is important to note that it is not appropriate to single out certain individuals and directly ask if they have disabilities.

Options to open the door for disclosure by individuals you suspect may have a disability include questions such as:

  • “Describe your high school program. Did you receive extra help in school?”
  • “Do you have specific concerns about entering this program?”
  • “Describe your areas of strength and areas you would like to improve.”

Note that many programs have intake forms with questions people may answer voluntarily  (regarding ethnicity, food stamps, housing vouchers, disability, etc.). Such voluntary check boxes are not the same as “asking directly“ and are administered to all individuals, thus no person or group is “singled out.”  Forms and processes like this are unlikely to violate confidentiality requirements.

We will take a closer look at issues of confidentiality next.

chapter.title: Activity: Share your ideas for improving your program’s self-disclosure support for individuals with LD
chapter.content:
Activity: Share your ideas for improving your program’s self-disclosure support for individuals with LD

Based on what you have learned so far in this course, consider the following questions:

  1. How might you improve or add to your intake process to better support self-disclosure by individuals with LD?
  2. How might you or your organization improve or add to what they currently do to support individuals with suspected LD to develop the skill of self-disclosure?

Please share your thoughts and read other teachers’ responses in the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group before moving on.
